channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: False Leads Set Back Hunt for Missing Malaysian Jet
item.description: Authorities widen the search area after suspected debris and an oil slick turn out to be unconnected to a Malaysia Airlines flight that vanished Saturday night.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER, KEITH BRADSHER and MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: A member of the military looked out of a helicopter during a search-and-rescue mission off the Tho Chu Islands of Vietnam on Monday.

item.title: The Lede: Jailed Leaders of Egypt’s 2011 Revolt Describe Beatings
item.description: In a letter smuggled out of Egypt’s Tora Prison over the weekend, a leading figure in the 2011 uprising who was recently jailed for protesting the current military-backed government, reported that prisoners are routinely tortured.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: No Winner Yet in El Salvador’s Close Presidential Race
item.description: An electoral tribunal said that the narrow margin made it impossible to declare a winner between Salvador Sánchez Cerén and Norman Quijano.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Supporters of Norman Quijano, a two-term mayor of San Salvador.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Managing the Discussion of the Missing Malaysian Jet
item.description: China’s authorities are juggling public grief and anger over the disappearance of a Malaysian airliner with what they really want high in the public mind: the current session of the National People’s Congress.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Relatives of passengers on the missing flight gathered in a hotel meeting room in Beijing on Monday, awaiting information.

item.title: Wall Street Slumps on Weak Chinese Trade Data
item.description: A decline in Chinese exports stoked fears of a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy, with markets in the United States backing off last week’s positive trend.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Russia Says It’s Preparing Counterproposals for Crimea as Russian Forces Strengthen Grip There
item.description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia said his government could not accept the “fait accompli” of the new Western-backed authorities in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian demonstrations on Monday in Donetsk, eastern Ukraine.

item.title: India Ink: First Charges Filed in $30 Billion Coal Scandal
item.description: Navabharat Power, now a unit of Essar Power, and its two former owners are accused of criminal conspiracy in its bid for a coal block.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: As Malaysia Expands Search Area for Missing Jet, Wide Speculation Over Its Fate
item.description: An expert said that if the Malaysia Airlines jet somehow veered off course over the Gulf of Thailand, it could be miles from where its flight data disappeared.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: Lens Blog: Life and Happiness in Siberia’s Cold
item.description: Departing from the images of frozen exile and gulags, a group of Russian photographers has compiled a nuanced portrait of a legendary, if misunderstood, region.
item.category: Initiative for Russian Culture at American University
item.dc:creator: By DIANA MARKOSIAN

item.title: Russian Oligarchs Fear Economic Casualties if Ukraine Crisis Escalates
item.description: Business titans face the prospect of losing access to Western finance if the United States and Europe carry out threats of tougher sanctions against Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Jordanian Judge Fatally Shot by Israeli Soldiers at Border Crossing
item.description: Israel said the man had tried to grab a soldier’s gun and brandished a metal bar, an account that was questioned by Jordanian and Palestinian officials.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Gerard Mortier, Opera Visionary and Patron of New Work, Dies at 70
item.description: His bold theatricality and updating of classical works marked his four-decade career as the leader of some of the world’s most important opera companies.
item.dc:creator: By ZACHARY WOOLFE
item.media:credit: Ed Alcock for The New York Times

item.title: Letter from Europe: Cold War Media Tactics Fuel Ukraine Crisis
item.description: Russia's propaganda onslaught on Crimea seems anachronistic in an age when Internet access was supposed to undercut the influence of state media.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 10
item.description: People celebrating Lathmar Holi at the Nandagram temple in Nandgaon, Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Boys throwing colored water on a woman at the Nandagram temple in Nandgaon, Uttar Pradesh, during the Hindu festival of Lathmar Holi.

item.title: Judge Bans Broadcast of Autopsy Testimony at Pistorius Murder Trial
item.description: Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star, was reported to have vomited during a pathologist’s testimony.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Anger Turns to Frustration Over Missing Jet
item.description: Insults and water bottles were thrown at Malaysia Airlines staff in Beijing on Monday over the lack of information about what has happened to Flight MH370.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: ‘Cleanest Village’ Questions Its Blessings Amid Influx of Visitors
item.description: Mawlynnong, a village in the northeastern state of Meghalaya, struggles to maintain its reputation as a pristine ecotourism destination against an onslaught of tourists.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Children in Mawlynnong, India, working to clean the village, where a reputation for tidiness brings tourists who aren't always cooperative.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Frustration Turns to Anger Over Missing Flight
item.description: In Beijing, friends and family of passengers on Flight MH370 grew increasingly angry over the lack of information about what happened to the Malaysian Airlines jet missing since Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A relative of a passenger on board Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 spoke with reporters on Monday at the Lido Hotel in Beijing.

item.title: Japan Won’t Alter Apology to World War II Sex Slaves
item.description: After rising criticism from South Korea, where many of the women came from, a top official said the government had no intention of rethinking the 1993 statement.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Life’s Guarantees: Death, Taxes and 7.5% Chinese G.D.P. Growth
item.description: A researcher at China’s economic planning agency is offering what Prime Minister Li Keqiang won’t: a guarantee that the country’s economy will hit its growth target this year.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Construction workers bicycled along a street in central Shanghai. Economic growth slowed last year to its lowest rate in more than a decade.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Warns of Risks in Plan to Retire Windows XP
item.description: Beijing argues that Microsoft is threatening both security and antipiracy efforts by asking users to upgrade from the Windows XP operating system, still used by nearly half the computers in China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Steven Sinofsky, then president of the Windows division at Microsoft, previewed the Windows 8 operating system in Shanghai in October 2012.

item.title: Search for Jet Compounds the Mystery
item.description: Planes and ships from a half-dozen countries joined the search for the plane that vanished with 239 people, including two who apparently used stolen passports to board.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Family members of Firman Chandra Siregar, an Indonesian passenger of flight MH370, watched television at their home in Medan, Indonesia, on Sunday.

item.title: Nigerians Ask Why Oil Funds Are Missing
item.description: In recent years, government commissions, parliamentary inquiries and civil society groups have all pointed to serious shortfalls in the disbursement of oil revenues.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Censors Hit Delete on a Party Chief’s Censorship Remarks
item.description: It seems that comments on microblogs about Internet censorship, even by senior Communist Party officials, can fall prey to China’s army of online minders.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Zhang Chunxian, Communist Party secretary of Xinjiang, was questioned by reporters on Thursday about the recent stabbing attack in Kunming.

item.title: Fears of Impending Change Darken Normally Lighthearted Odessa
item.description: As Crimea prepares for a referendum on joining the Russian Federation, residents in Odessa and in other Russian-speaking areas throughout the south and the east of Ukraine find themselves swaying, to greater and lesser degrees, between east and west.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boulevard in Odessa, Ukraine. The Crimean crisis is a sobering moment for Odessa, where the municipal holiday is April Fools’ Day, called Humorina.
